Pretty much completely missed all the important bits in 9.9999... seconds.
Angles and Refraction!  It's all about the angles that the  light comes directly from the sun, and refracts both entering and leaving the water droplets causing it to be separated into distinct wavelengths and returned back.      Each water droplet acts as a prism to separate the wavelengths of light as the light enters the drop and again when it leaves the drop.    Each wavelength is refracted and comes back at a relatively distinct angle.    From your fixed vantage point, you can't see all the different colors coming from a single droplet at different angles, but many droplets at different angles to the viewer each present a specific wavelength back to your location.   The very same drops viewed from a different vantage point will show a different color (or none at all).    

For the main bow, red is refracted and returned at the greatest angle, so it is seen in the droplets furthest from the center of the circle, or in this case the top edge of the main bow.   Bluer light is returned at a lower angle so it is visible from the droplets closer to the center of the circle.     It's a bow (arc of a circle) and not a line, because the angle from sun  (a relatively small point of light behind you) to droplet in front of you, then double refracted back toward you is always the same for a given wavelength, and only the arc of a circle can define that geometric relationship.

The 2nd rainbow occurs because the prism effect of the water droplet does not separate and return the colors in only a single set of angles, but multiple times, in multiple groupings.   The 2nd bow returns the colors in reverse order.  red refracts at a lower angle (closer to center of circle) while blue at a greater angle (further from the center of circle).

BTW, the very center of the circle of which the rainbow's arc is a part, is always wherever the shadow of your own head falls.
